articles.headline: Health Bill Would Add 24 Million Uninsured but Save $337 Billion, Report Says
articles.snippet: The judgment by the Congressional Budget Office did not back up the president’s promise of providing health care for everyone but may help bring in rebellious conservatives.
articles.abstract: The judgment by the Congressional Budget Office did not back up the president’s promise of providing health care for everyone but may help bring in rebellious conservatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House Republican plan to replace the Affordable Care Act would increase the number of people without health insurance by 24 million by 2026, while slicing $337 billion off federal budget deficits over that time, the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office said Monday.
articles.byline: By Thomas Kaplan and Robert Pear

articles.headline: William Ackman Sells Pershing Fund’s Stake in Valeant
articles.snippet: The hedge fund of the billionaire, who had defended the troubled drug maker for months in the face of a stock plunge, sold some 27 million shares.
articles.abstract: The hedge fund of the billionaire, who had defended the troubled drug maker for months in the face of a stock plunge, sold some 27 million shares.
articles.lead_paragraph: William A. Ackman, a billionaire investor, staked his reputation as a savvy stock picker on his ability to oversee a turnaround at Valeant Pharmaceuticals International.

articles.headline: Solar Experiment Lets Neighbors Trade Energy Among Themselves
articles.snippet: Dozens of homes and businesses in Brooklyn have been wired into a microgrid, which allows members to exchange excess-electricity credits.
articles.abstract: Dozens of homes and businesses in Brooklyn have been wired into a microgrid, which allows members to exchange excess-electricity credits.
articles.lead_paragraph: Brooklyn is known the world over for things small-batch and local, like designer clogs, craft bourbon and artisanal sauerkraut.

articles.headline: Preet Bharara: ‘Sheriff of Wall Street’ or Pragmatic Showman?
articles.snippet: The ousted United States attorney has been criticized as being too harsh and too soft on Wall Street, but he may simply have been a pragmatist.
articles.abstract: The ousted United States attorney has been criticized as being too harsh and too soft on Wall Street, but he may simply have been a pragmatist.
articles.lead_paragraph: When it comes to policing Wall Street, there are two distinct narratives about Preet Bharara’s tenure as the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York.

articles.headline: Steve King, Hurling Insults at Immigrants, Is Rebuked by His Own Party
articles.snippet: The comment on Twitter about immigrants by the Iowa representative was praised by the white supremacist David Duke, but many Republicans were quick to condemn his inflammatory rhetoric.
articles.abstract: The comment on Twitter about immigrants by the Iowa representative was praised by the white supremacist David Duke, but many Republicans were quick to condemn his inflammatory rhetoric.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Long before Donald J. Trump took aim at immigrants, there was Representative Steve King of Iowa.

articles.headline: Iceland, Symbol of Financial Crisis, Finally Lifts Capital Controls
articles.snippet: The move closes a fraught chapter in the country’s economic history, but Iceland faces new challenges as growth rebounds — some say too quickly for its own good.
articles.abstract: The move closes a fraught chapter in the country’s economic history, but Iceland faces new challenges as growth rebounds — some say too quickly for its own good.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nine years after a giant banking crash made Iceland a symbol of the global financial crisis, the government on Tuesday effectively declared that financial stability had been restored as it ended longstanding restrictions on the flow of money into and out of the country.

articles.headline: Ban on Head Scarves at Work Is Legal, E.U. Court Rules
articles.snippet: Restrictions on religious garments are allowed as long as they are applied to employees of all faiths, the European Court of Justice found.
articles.abstract: Restrictions on religious garments are allowed as long as they are applied to employees of all faiths, the European Court of Justice found.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The European Union’s highest court waded into the politically explosive issue of public expressions of Muslim identity on Tuesday, finding that private employers can ban female workers from wearing head scarves on the job.

articles.headline: Fed’s Challenge, After Raising Rates, May Be Existential
articles.snippet: In a time of populist policy making and popular anger, the central bank faces a renewed struggle over its independence.
articles.abstract: In a time of populist policy making and popular anger, the central bank faces a renewed struggle over its independence.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is the Fed at risk for real this time?

articles.headline: Hudson’s Bay and Neiman Marcus Are Said to Be in Merger Talks
articles.snippet: A deal would put the struggling high-end retailer under the same umbrella as Saks Fifth Avenue and Lord & Taylor and highlight wider troubles at department stores.
articles.abstract: A deal would put the struggling high-end retailer under the same umbrella as Saks Fifth Avenue and Lord & Taylor and highlight wider troubles at department stores.
articles.lead_paragraph: The unrest in the department store business seems to have no end in sight. Now potentially on the horizon: a tie-up that would turn several of the biggest luxury rivals into siblings.
articles.byline: By Rachel Abrams and Ian Austen
